
Tags: #ml #stats 

------------------------------------------
![formulat](data:image/png;base64,)

Mean squared error tells about the difference between Predicted value and actual values from data set in a regression. Less MSE value means our model will predict more accurately. 
We use different Optimisation techniques to get less MSE. It is also used as loss function... lesser the loss better the accuracy of the model.

#### Advantages:
1. differentiable
2. There is one local /  one global minimum
#### Disadvantages:
1. Not Robust ( Outliers effects it.)
2. Unit of values changes as we are squaring it.

---
### GPT says:

Mean squared error (MSE) is a commonly used statistical metric that measures the average squared difference between the predicted and actual values of a regression problem. It is calculated by taking the average of the squared differences between the predicted and actual values over a set of data points.

MSE is widely used in machine learning as a measure of how well a regression model is performing. Specifically, it is often used as a ==loss function== that the model tries to minimize during training. In other words, the goal of training a regression model is often to minimize the MSE, as doing so should lead to more accurate predictions on new, unseen data.

MSE is related to other important statistical concepts, such as variance and bias. Specifically, the MSE can be decomposed into two components: variance and bias squared. Variance represents how much the predictions of a model vary for different training sets, while bias represents how much the predictions of a model differ from the true values of the data. In other words, the MSE can be seen as a balance between these two factors: a model with high variance will have a high MSE because it is overfitting to the training data, while a model with high bias will also have a high MSE because it is underfitting to the data.

----

In optimization problems, such as those encountered in machine learning, we often seek to find the minimum value of a function. The terms "local minimum" and "global minimum" describe different kinds of minimum values of a function.

A local minimum is a point in the function where the value is lower than all other points in the immediate vicinity, but it may not be the lowest value in the entire function. In other words, there could be other points elsewhere in the function that have lower values. On the other hand, a global minimum is the lowest value in the entire function, meaning that there are no other points with lower values.

A [[Convex Function]] is a function that has a single global minimum. It is a function in which the line segment between any two points on the function lies entirely above the function. In other words, a convex function is a function that "curves upwards" and has no local minima. A hyperbola, on the other hand, is a non-convex function that has multiple local minima.

In regression machine learning, we often use the mean squared error (MSE) as a loss function to measure the difference between the predicted and actual values. The MSE can be seen as a function that we are trying to minimize during training. The shape of the MSE function is important because it can affect how well the model is able to generalize to new data.

If the MSE function is convex, then it has a single global minimum, and any optimization algorithm is guaranteed to find that minimum. This means that the model is more likely to converge to a good solution during training, and it is less likely to overfit the training data.

However, if the MSE function is non-convex, with multiple local minima, then it is possible for the optimization algorithm to converge to a suboptimal solution. This means that the model may not generalize as well to new data, and it is more likely to overfit the training data.

In summary, the concepts of local minima, global minima, convex functions, and hyperbolas are all related to the optimization of the MSE loss function in regression machine learning. Understanding these concepts can help us design and train better machine learning models that are more likely to generalize well to new data.
